repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Rough draft for #3279 using https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/5f7ebe56b90dcea733fc5c47b5a0e32de39d4419 as inspiration

I realize the Py2 compat is not correct; could use some guidance on how to best tackle if you have insight to offer

comment_data.body: You're definitely interested in what the generated file is compiled in, rather than what version of Python Cython is running in. You should be able to Cythonize a file in Py2 then compile it for Py3
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2312,6 +2312,35 @@ def _optimise_generic_builtin_method_call(self, node, attr_name, function, arg_l
         return ExprNodes.CachedBuiltinMethodCallNode(
             node, function.obj, attr_name, arg_list)
 
+    PyObject_String_func_type = PyrexTypes.CFuncType(
+        Builtin.str_type, [
+            PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("org", PyrexTypes.py_object_type, None)
+            ])
+
+    def _handle_simple_function_str(self, node, function, pos_args):
+        """Optimize single argument calls to str().
+        """
+        if len(pos_args) != 1:
+            if len(pos_args) == 0:
+                return ExprNodes.StringNode(node.pos, value=EncodedString(), constant_result='')
+            return node
+        arg = pos_args[0]
+
+        if basestring is str:  # python 2

comment_data.body:
That would be Py3 (not Py2), but more importantly, we wouldn't be interested in the runtime environment under which Cython is running, but the compile time configuration of the module it's compiling.

Here, though, I don't think we need to care at all. Just follow the example of the `unicode()` call optimisation. The `str()` optimisation is probably going to be very similar (using `str_type` instead of `unicode_type` obviously, etc.). Tests will tell.

comment_data.body: This should be the name of a function defined in `StringTools.c`, which is then loaded and included by `load_cached()` below (by the name of the `////…` section in the file).

comment_data.body: Makes sense. Is there a canonical way to detect this? Looking at the unicode impl I think it was doing it by checking if unicode is a builtin, which maybe could do here as well (just felt out of place)

comment_data.body: The `PY_MAJOR_VERSION` macro in the C file. But I'm not convinced you actually need it - the [linked issue implies](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3279) that `PyObject_Str` should generally be OK.

comment_data.body: The unicode implementation has a check for Py_None which if true gets wrapped in `PYUNICODE("None")`. I didn't see an equivalent STR macro in (what I assume should be) the CPython source, but I don't required in any case for tests to pass
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1219,3 +1219,25 @@ static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyUnicode_Unicode(PyObject *obj) {
 #define __Pyx_PyObject_Unicode(obj) \
     (likely(PyUnicode_CheckExact(obj)) ? __Pyx_NewRef(obj) : PyObject_Unicode(obj))
 #endif
+
+
+//////////////////// PyStr_Str.proto ////////////////////
+
+static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyStr_Str(PyObject *obj);/*proto*/
+
+//////////////////// PyStr_Str ////////////////////
+
+static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyStr_Str(PyObject *obj) {
+    return __Pyx_NewRef(obj);

comment_data.body:
I think this is necessary - when Cython believes something is a fixed Python type it will (usually) also accept `None`.

For `PyObject_Str` that's no problem - if it's passed `None` then the conversion to string happens through the regular mechanism. However it is a problem for this shortcut which only increases the reference count (i.e. `__Pyx_PyStr_Str` needs to handle `str` or `None`, but `__Pyx_PyObject_Str` handles `None` using the normal Python mechanism).

+    return __Pyx_NewRef(obj);

comment_data.body:
No - that's the point I was making. When you type something as `str` it really means `str or None`.

See https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/extension_types.html#extension-types-and-none - I know this is discussed in terms of extension types, but it is the same.

comment_data.body:
It's not a real macro - it's a preprocessing that Cython does to the utility code https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/e9d7fd45a2e829ee93980b1c0612f8476a46431d/Cython/Compiler/Code.py#L530 .

It doesn't look like there's an equivalent for string, so you might have to make one... maybe... I'm not 100% confident

comment_data.body: Use `PYIDENT("None")`. It creates a string that Python would accept as an identifier, and that means a `str`, in both Py2 and Py3.

comment_data.body:
Probably just a typo ("arg"), but let's use "obj" instead (because, why not).
```suggestion
            PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("obj", PyrexTypes.py_object_type, None)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2312,6 +2312,38 @@ def _optimise_generic_builtin_method_call(self, node, attr_name, function, arg_l
         return ExprNodes.CachedBuiltinMethodCallNode(
             node, function.obj, attr_name, arg_list)

comment_data.body:
There's already code that makes `PyString_CheckExact()` available in Py3, so this is just
```suggestion
#define __Pyx_PyObject_Str(obj) \
    (likely(PyString_CheckExact(obj)) ? __Pyx_NewRef(obj) : PyObject_Str(obj))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1219,3 +1219,27 @@ static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyUnicode_Unicode(PyObject *obj) {
 #define __Pyx_PyObject_Unicode(obj) \
     (likely(PyUnicode_CheckExact(obj)) ? __Pyx_NewRef(obj) : PyObject_Unicode(obj))
 #endif
+
+
+//////////////////// PyStr_Str.proto ////////////////////
+
+static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyStr_Str(PyObject *obj);/*proto*/
+
+//////////////////// PyStr_Str ////////////////////
+
+static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyStr_Str(PyObject *obj) {
+    if (unlikely(obj == Py_None))
+        obj = PYUNICODE("None");
+    return __Pyx_NewRef(obj);
+}
+
+
+//////////////////// PyObject_Str.proto ////////////////////
+
+#if PY_MAJOR_VERSION >= 3
+#define __Pyx_PyObject_Str(obj) \
+    (likely(PyUnicode_CheckExact(obj)) ? __Pyx_NewRef(obj) : PyObject_Str(obj))
+#else
+#define __Pyx_PyObject_Str(obj) \
+    (likely(PyString_CheckExact(obj)) ? __Pyx_NewRef(obj) : PyObject_Str(obj))
+#endif

comment_data.body:
@scoder

Is the commented out bit for `str` still true?
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5ab92ce56e3826bb0743b32b2f8a2270bf199222/Cython/Compiler/Builtin.py#L349-L355

I'm struggling to understand why it should be true - at least in Python 2.7 `PyObject_Str` looks pretty diligent at ensuring that it returns a string?

It seems that either the assignment of `Builtin.str_type` in this PR might be dubious, or (better) that `str` can be added back to `types_that_return_their_instance` which would be nice because it'd allow other things to use the type earlier.

             node, function.obj, attr_name, arg_list)
 
+    PyObject_String_func_type = PyrexTypes.CFuncType(
+        Builtin.str_type, [

comment_data.body: In Py2, `str()` is allowed to return a unicode object. So, yes, it should say `object` here. Thanks!

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Optimize builtin str calls
